div.head: Add Links For References (Both In-Text and External)

list.item: Create links for any references in the text, e.g., "see page ###" or "see Bibliography." Links for in-text references are created with the ptr element and external references (to other 84000 texts or other web pages) are created with the ref element. Links to Kangyur/Tangyur texts that are not yet published should be marked with a the coded comment <Reference Toh #### F.###.b>.

It is also important to check the introduction and endnotes for any intext references to chapters or sections and add ptr tags anywhere the reader might want to follow a link. In the introduction the translator may have pointed out sections of the translation using Dege folio references; unless these mentions are specifically referring to the Tibetan source text or the structure thereof, these folio references should be changed to the milestone numbers generated in the Reading Room -- according to what can be referenced most conveniently by the reader.
For further guidelines for creating links see Appendix B.4: Cross References and Links.

div.head: See how the Text Looks on the Web Page

list.item: Go through the text again in web display, making sure everything looks okay.

It is helpful at this point to put the web page in “editor mode.” This underlines the linked glossary terms for you. Otherwise, in the regular display, it underlines them but then they will disappear after a few seconds, which will be frustrating when your are checking the links. An additional benefit of editor mode is that all of the collapsed sections of the text (Intro, Translation, Notes, etc...) will be expanded by default, so that you can more easily search for terms in the web display with CTRL-F. To put the page in editor mode, simply add the following text to the end of the URL web address: ?view-mode=editor

At this point you should check to see that the glossary is linking to the right terms. In the summary and introduction in particular there may be many instances of a word linking to the glossary when it shouldn’t, for example in the phrase “in terms of…” the word “term” might link to the glossary for the technical meaning of “term”; or to take another example, in the phrase “with respect to…” the word “respect” might link to “respect” as in devotion (these are just two out of many examples). Note, the translator guidelines [G4] instructs translators to flag instances of glossary terms that are only relevant to specific passages with the “†” symbol. They are also instructed to specify glossary entries as verbs (vb), nouns (n), or adjectives (adj) in cases where the glossary entry is only intended to link to one form of the word and not others, for example "play" or "appropriate". If they have done so then, don't leave these markers in the text, but replace them with the markup described in the following section. However, it is likely that a lot of these terms will be missed so you should also scan through the text in editor mode for any of these improperly linked terms.

Also check that the highlighted terms correspond to their definition given in the Glossary. For example, although term ཁམས་ can refer to the 18 dhatus, it can also sometimes refer to the 4 or 5 elements (earth, air, fire, water and space--although usually the term འབྱུང་པ་/པོ་ is used for this set). Both cases may be translated by the English word "element," but if the definition only mentions the 18 dhatus, then instances of the latter case of the 4 or 5 elements should not be linked.

To fix these instances add the term type="ignore" tag to the ones that should not be linked. Optionally the mode attribute may be added to the gloss element in the glossary. If the mode is set to mode="match" (this is the default mode, by the way), you will be able to block strings in the text you don't want to link by marking them with this term type="ignore" tag. If you change it to mode="marked", it will only link with strings in the text that are tagged with the term element (you will need to mark each instance of the term individually in this case).

In these cases you can save yourself some time when choosing between the "marked" or "match" modes. It is good to think about which mode will require the least amount of tags. Usually this will be the default "match" mode, but it varies from case to case.

In some cases there may be three or more glossary entries with the same word. For example, if three people in the text have the same name. In this case, the instances may be distinguished using mode="marked" and adding @ref ids to all the instances of that name marked with a term element. Please see Appendix C for details and examples of this.

If there are any instances in the web display where there is a term in the glossary that is showing "0 instances in this text" (in the right-hand column of the glossary), you should find out if that term is actually in the text. There may be a spelling error, a diacritic error, or some other reason why it isn't linking to the glossary entry. Sometimes there is a glossary term that really isn't in the text (possibly because it was in the introduction and later removed). If this is the case make a note about it in the final list of questions and issues to address when you have finished the text.

There are several subtle points for polishing the final glossary. In some cases alternatives may need to be added to link particular terms and in some cases the glossary terms will need to be checked against the original Tibetan. So we have created a separate Appendix C that explains how the glossary works, along with a few further tips for editing it. Please take a look at Appendix C here.

div.head: Search Other Published Texts for Links to the Text You Have Just Finished
div.p: As has been mentioned above, any cross references that should be linked to future publications have been marked by a coded comment: <Reference Toh #### F.###.b>. After the four digit Toh number the folio number is optional, you can also add "-#" if it is a large text divided into chapters like the Vinaya, but the initial of this string up to the fourth digit of the Toh number must follow this exact format. This is so the comment may be found in a search at the time when that future text is published.

Conjointly, now that you have nearly completed the markup for a new text to be published, you should search through all of the previously published texts for this same string with the Toh number of this text you are just about to complete. It is important that this step is done after the milestones have been finalized, as cross links usually will linked by targeting those specific milestones.

To search for references in previously published texts, go to the data source explorer in oxgyen and right-click on the "translations folder" (For now just the Kangyur translations will suffice, but the Tengyur translations will need to be searched as well whenever we start publishing those).

After right-clicking select "Find/Replace in Files". With this command you can search all the published files for the following string:
Reference Toh ####
(be sure that the "Ignore extra whitespaces" box is checked. This will ensure that the code is found even if it occurs across a line break.)

So for example you would search Reference Toh 0120 for Toh 120. Now you will find any cross references that need to be updated. Go into those texts and update those links by removing the comment and adding a ref that targets the URL of the appropriate milestone. For guidelines on creating cross textual links see Appendix B.4: Cross References and Links.

div.head: Final Details
div.p: A few final things to look out for while going through your final run of the text:

list.item: Check for extra unwanted blank spaces.
Double check links and make sure they go to the right places.

Make sure links aren't missing. Sometimes if the little "#" is missing or misplaced in the "target" attribute in the ptrs then the reference won't appear at all and you will see text like "(see above, .)" without anything coming after it.
Do a search for comment tags that may refer to issues that haven't been addressed. To find them you can do a quick search for "<!--".

list.head: Search through the text and correct any erroneous straight apostrophes and quote marks. Note that the translator guidelines says to use typographical apostrophes and quote marks (‘ ’ “ ”) not straight ones (' "). All Wylie Tibetan transliteration of the a-chung character should use a right-curling apostrophe ’ not a left-curling one. One exception to this rule is for strings of Sanskrit transliteration which may use a straight apostrophe ' to represent the avagraha character; this is allowed so long as it is done consistently. Otherwise straight apostrophes should be avoided unless there is some pertinent reason to include them. These straight apostrophes and quotes are easy to miss and often can slip unnoticed into our publications, so please run the following searches before submitting your final markup:
list.item: (1) Check for straight apostrophes ' : This is easily done with a search-and-replace command for the ' character. Just make sure you check each one, most of them will need to be replaced with right-curling apostrophes but some will need to be replaced with a left-curling one.

(2) Check for straight double quote marks " : This is a little trickier as straight quote marks are used in the XML tags. To find them in the text and ignore all the tags open the CTRL/SHIFT/H, select "All open files" in the scope and search for the straight double quote " but in the field that says "Restrict to XPath:" enter the code //text() this will search for the straight double quote only in the text but not the tags.
(3) Check for left-curling apostrophe in Wylie Transliteration: Again use the XPath/XQuery and search for //*[@xml:lang = 'Bo-Ltn'][contains(data(), "‘")]

(4) Occasionally the unicode for a "modified word apostrophe" (U+02BC) may have been entered into the document. These look identical in the Oxygen editor and in most fonts in general. However they display inconsistently with each other in the Reading Room and can interfere with data searches in the Tibetan Wylie. Since this unicode has been depreciated in most word processors it is unlikely to occur, but you should check for any (U+02BC)s by searching the following character: ʼ and all of these should be replaced with right curling single quote marks (U+2019), which you can paste using this character here: ’ (They look the same but they are not. Notice with the Unicode identifier at the bottom of the screen in Oxygen)

Within the text's introduction and body notes should always be flush with the preceding character with no space between them. Occasionally, the note element may be separated by a linebreak in the XML when it is formatted or when it originally went through the script. To correct these instances you can search the regular expression: \s+<note place="end" and replace with <note place="end"

Check folio refs inside mantras. There is currently a rare bug where if there is a folio reference, e.g., inside a mantra element and that element is flush with the preceding p element, then the folio ref will not link in the reading room. For example:

This is a mantra.

In this example the folio reference F.102.a will not display the eKangyur when it is clicked in the reading room. In this rare situation where they are directly next to each other (if there is any characters between them like a quote mark, space, or letter this problem doesn't occur), the fix for this is to simply put a single line break between the p and mantra. So from the example above: This is a mantra. (This is a line break in the XML itself NOT an lb element). This will not alter the text in anyway as it appears in the reading room but it will fix the broken link for F.102.a to the eKangyur. To search for this issue you can simple search with this regular expression: ]+?>

Address any final schema errors. Occasionally, the schema may need to be updated to accommodate a new type of formatting. Or, if a note uses a term in a language that hasn't been used in a published text yet, then that ISO 639-1 code may need to be added to the schema. In either case contact me about this (Celso) and I will add adjust the schema as needed.
Note any formatting or anything else that just looks wrong or awkward.
Make note of any grammar or editing errors that you think may have been missed in the copy editing phase. You can also add this to your final list of questions and issues.

Run Automated Tests from Utilities
As a final step run the series of automated tests from the Translations Tab on the Utilities Page. You will find a link next to the text title that says "Run tests". Note these are the same tests that are performed from the "Tests" tab, but this "Run tests" link only performs them on the individual text (running tests on all the texts at once uses a lot of the server's resources so this should only be done when testing global updates). It the server will perform a series of tests and display the results. If any of the tests fail, click on that entry and it should display the explanation for the error. Most of these you should be able to resolve, but on occasion there may be an error that is difficult to diagnose or sometimes there is a unique anomaly causing the error and the test itself needs to be updated. In either case please notify the lead tech (dominic.latham@84000.co) about any of the test failures that can't be resolved.

div.head: List any Outstanding Issues from the Reading Room Revisions Sheet

list.item: As you work on the text, make a running list of any problems or issues that you cannot fix yourself and make this into a final list of questions and issues. There are often a lot of things that come up: some of them should be addressed by the project editor, some by a copyeditor and some issues may need be updated in the schema or addressed by the technician. This list should be pasted into the Reading Room Revisions spreadsheet, which you can access through this link. There are several sheets within this document. Use the sheet entitled "Texts in Markup" and create a new heading for the text you are working on. There are also workflow instructions for how to post issues within the Reading Room Revisions sheet itself, at the very top of the "Texts in Markup" sheet.

You may find solutions to these issues as you go, and if you just need your solutions or corrections to be checked by one of the editors, then assign the first "status" column with the orange label "check". Otherwise assign any new issues as "new".

From the "Pending on" column you can assign this issue to appropriate party to check:
Any copyeditor issues (spelling, grammar, and style issues) may be assigned to Laura (laura.goetz@84000.co), or as a backup Konchog (konchog@84000.co).
Any authoritative editorial issues should be assigned to the project editor for that text.
In general we want to avoid burdening the editorial directors (John and Andreas), with editorial problems that could be resolved by the project editors, but sometimes there may be some important issues that require a directorial decision. In such cases, first check with the manager of publications, Mike (mike.engle@84000.co) and he will forward such issues to the directors as is necessary.
If the text is displaying correctly but the schema needs to be updated (a new element or value, e.g., xml:lang needs to be validated) Notify Celso (celso.wilkinson@84000.co).
Any technical issues to do specifically with the webdisplay/parser should be addressed to Dom (dominic.latham@84000.co) and cc Celso as well.

As mentioned in the sheet's workflow instructions, you can assign issues to specific parties by making a comment and typing the "@" or "+" character, then selecting them from a drop down list. Or, if you prefer it's fine to just email that person directly. It's best to give a suggestion for how the issue may be resolved either from the "comments" column or by email if necessary.

Occasionally, for issues that everyone may want to discuss, you can also notify or email one of the departments as a whole with the following groups:
84000-markup-editors@googlegroups.com -- address all markup.
84000-copyeditors@googlegroups.com -- all copyeditors.
all_editors@84000.co -- addresses all project editors (cc's John and Andreas for overview).

As these issues are resolved please clean up your text's section in the review sheet. For anything that is fully resolved you can mark its status as "archive" and move it to the "resolved archive" sheet (or just delete it if it is inconsequential). If it seems to be an issue that may come up again and may be useful to reference in the future, you can also add it to the "reference archive" sheet.

When all the final issues have been resolved or noted for the final review in the Reading Room Revisions sheet, notify the lead markup editor; the markup will be reviewed one more time them and then they will update the status to "2", ("Markup Completed, and awaiting final proofing before release").

If there are any parts of this TEI editor's checklist that need to be clarified or updated you can contact Celso to make those updates. You can either assign the task to him on the Reading Room Revisions Sheet or email him at celso.wilkinson@gmail.com.

div.head: Italics
div.p: In a given text, words or phrases may be italicized for different reasons. The need to express both presentation information (that text is italicized) as well as the semantic information about why it is italicized must be addressed. That is why instead of simply using the hi element, for example, the voices below form the markup menu for text that needs to be italicized:

list.item: distinct terms, words, or phrases singled out (in any language, but use this only when a "foreign" tag is not applicable).
emph words or phrases italicized for emphasis or rhetorical effect.
foreign xml:lang="" foreign words or phrases in any language.
foreign type="term" xml:lang="" a foreign term or phrase other than a quote or title, such as a term or phrase in parentheses following its translation, or a foreign term or phrase left untranslated.
title xml:lang="" title of a work (in any language).
foreign xml:lang="__-Ltn" Wylie or other type of Roman transliteration (excluding European languages, which should not have the "-Ltn" appendage).
foreign type="quote" xml:lang="" quotations from other texts.

mantra should be used to italicize complete mantras, however this is a bit more complex because some parts of mantras maybe translated into English. See Appendix B.6 for more about how to markup mantras.

div.p: Note that sometimes there may be some overlap between what distinguishes the italics tag used for a “term” vs. a “quote.” In such cases you can use your own discretion, but in general italics used for a “term” are for specific a word or phrase that is left un-translated usually because it is technical, untranslatable, or for some other reason. In contrast the italics used for a “quote” are for italics used for a word or phrase citing a specific instance in a source text either to corroborate the English translation, or to note some difference between two or more sources. Both tags are rendered the same in the end, so this isn’t a critical call to make. There is no need spend time looking up italics to determine whether or not they are found in sources, but just keep this general principle in mind when distinguishing the proper tag for italics.

Note that Tibetan script and Chinese characters should be given the xml:lang value of "bo" and "zh" respectively, while Tibetan, Chinese, and Sanskrit romanized transliteration should have the values of "Bo-Ltn," "Zh-Ltn," and "Sa-Ltn" respectively. For other languages use the list of ISO 639-1 codes to find the appropriate xml:lang value. Most often an Asian language will be translated into the Roman script and, therefore, the first letter of the ISO 639-1 code should be capitalized followed by "-Ltn". Thus a Thai term "th" in Romanized script should be coded "Th-Ltn." If the term is a European language or the native script of that language is used, then use the two letter code as usual, e.g., "fr" (French), "la" (Latin), etc.

For the most part, these tags should be added during the copy editing phase in the 84000 Template.docx. In this phase they will be added as styles in MS Word, but will be transformed into the appropriate tag by our scripts. However, as we can't add a style for every language in the template, the markup editor will need look up and edit the tags for any uncommon languages, which will be marked through the script as xml:lang="Input Language." The markup editor should also keep an eye out for errors, or italicized text that was missed. However, the script should render all unmarked italics with a "<fix>" tag, which will be highlighted as an error by the schema.

div.head: Types of Divisions
div.p: Div elements are used to mark different sections within a text. This is of particular importance as the head tag can only follow directly after a "div" marker or another head tag. The main sections of the text are marked as follows:

list.item: div type="summary" Wraps the Summary section.
div type="acknowledgement" Wraps the Acknowledgement section.
div type="prologue" Wraps the Prologue (if there is one).
div type="preface" Wraps the Preface (if there is one).
div type="introduction" Wraps the Introduction.
div type="translation" Wraps the entire translation.
div type="notes" Wraps the notes section; this section is needed for displaying abbreviations.
div type="listBibl" Contains a group of bibl elements, wraps the bibliography.
div type="appendix" To wrap the appendix of a text, e.g. a Sanskrit Appendix (if there is one).
div type="colophon" Wraps the colophon. (Note, the schema only allows this nested as a second level div after all second level "sections" and/or "chapters")

div.p: Within those major document units or divisions, there are other sub units, especially chapters or their equivalent. Both chapter and section refer to the same hierarchical level in the XML. Chapters are the type value used in the body of the text when they have been specified as chapters by the translator. Section is used for equivalent level sectioning that has not been called a chapter. Examples for the latter are sectioned bibliographies, where the whole of the bibliography has multiple sections organized by source type. In that case div type="section" is used instead of div type="chapter". From a structural point of view, however, they are the same.

list.item: div type="chapter" Wraps a chapter that is part of the translation.
div type="section" Wraps a section of the TEI document.

div.head: Outlines and Lists
div.p: Sometimes the introduction of a text will provide an outline, particularly in the case of a longer or more complicated text. Within the TEI XML these outlines should be constructed using the list and item elements. For a complex outline with many levels of subsections, the outline itself should be contained in a list, and each section should be contained in an item within that list. Then, for each sub section, a new list element should be nested within those items, which in turn contains its own subsections with item elements, and so forth for as many subsections as necessary. Note that if the list is marked up as type="bullet" it will be indented. A good way to render the outline in a clear way is to mark up the first list as type="section" and all subsequent lists as type="bullet"; then the major sections will be separated by vertical spacing and all the subsections will be indented. For an example see the following outline from "The Baskets Display" (Toh 116): The XML markup from this outline in Toh. 116 is shown below.

item.p: I. Sūtra narrative: Buddha Śākyamuni is in the Jetavana Monastery when lights appear, transforming the monastery’s appearance. Bodhisattva Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin questions Buddha Śākyamuni about this, and the Buddha states that the cause of the lights is Avalokiteśvara visiting Avīci hell and then the city of the pretas.

1. Buddha Śākyamuni’s narrative: Avalokiteśvara appears in the Avīci hell and liberates beings. As a result, Yama’s creatures go to Yama and describe Avalokiteśvara’s arrival. Yama goes to Avalokiteśvara and praises him.
II. Sūtra narrative: Buddha Śākyamuni responds to a question from Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin about whether Avalokiteśvara has left the hell.
1. Buddha Śākyamuni’s narrative: Avalokiteśvara leaves the hells, visits the city of the pretas, and liberates them from their suffering. This very sūtra sounds in their realm.

div.p: This will allow the outline to be properly displayed in the 84000 reading room. For more simple outlines that have a one-level list, use the list with type="bullet" if the items are one or two sentences long (for an example, see Toh. 11 here), and use type="section" if the items are longer sections of text (see also Toh. 11 here). The "bullet" and "section" types can be used in alternation however they are needed, just note that "section" will have vertical spacing between each item, and "bullet" will be indented.

The head element resting within the list tag, but outside of the item tag can be used to create a bold heading at the top of a list. Alternatively, within an item tag a label attribute may be used to the same effect. See Toh. 11 again for an example, along with the following XML markup from that same section:

list.head: I. UNDERSTANDING OF ALL PHENOMENA
list.p: The first fourteen chapters of the text concern the theoretical understanding of all phenomena, which is the first goal to be realized. Śāradvatī­putra acts as Lord Buddha’s interlocutor in the first nine chapters, with Su­bhūti making his initial appearance in chapter 10.

item.label: Chapters 1 and 2
item.p: In response to a question about what is the transcendent perfection of wisdom which bodhisattvas are to perfect, Lord Buddha replies that it is the absence of fixation with respect to all phenomena, all meditative experiences, all causal attributes acquired by bodhisattvas, all fruitional attributes manifested by buddhas, and all attainments up to and including omniscience. along with unconditioned phenomena, such as the abiding nature of all things and the finality of existence, these are all attributes with respect to which a great bodhisattva being should cultivate detachment. Bodhisattvas do perceive such phenomena distinctly, but only on the relative level; in an ultimate sense they consider them to be illusory, in the manner of a dream and so forth.

item.label: Chapter 3
item.p: Fixation may ensue when those phenomena and attributes are considered as permanent or impermanent, as conducive to happiness or suffering, with self or without self, empty or not empty, with signs or signless, having or lacking aspirations, calm or not calm, void or not void, afflicted or purified, arising or not arising, ceasing or not ceasing, and as entities or non-entities. Deluded minds would view these phenomena and attributes as absolutely existent whereas bodhisattvas should train so as to understand that they are all non-apprehensible—mere designations and conceptualizations.

div.head: Internal Links Created with the ptr Element:

item.label: Milestones:
item.p: Cross references in the text that refer to milestones will be added using a ptr element with the "target" attribute. The value of the target should be a hashmark ("#") followed by the xml:id value of the milestone that is to be linked. For example: See . The milestone number as it appears on the webpage may be listed as a comment afterwards, but the parser will automatically show the milestone number in the web display. This way even if the milestones shift around it will still display and link to the correct milestone on the web page.

One important point about adding references to the introduction. When you mark up introductions with internal ptr references to the translation, even if the translator has used source-text folio references (e.g F.108.a) for the cross-reference, it would be helpful if you could replace them by links to the relevant milestone in the translation. For most readers that will make much more sense. Of course the translators have no choice, because at the time they put such cross-references in there are no milestones.

If you can’t identify exactly the passage and its milestone, you can of course leave it as the folio reference, and John or someone will make the change during final editing. And, of course, if the reference is really all (and only) about a Tibetan passage in the source text, and the translation is irrelevant, a folio reference makes more sense.

item.p: Notes and Bibliography entries work in exactly the same way:, for the target attribute, simply use the xml:id value contained in the note or bibl element that needs to be linked. You can also link to the general bibliography section with the target value "#bibliography." For example:

div.head: Tables
div.p: Occasionally translators may present a table in their translation. Tables can be used anywhere in the text or even contained within an endnote. The XSL script should be equipped to convert tables from the DOCX document to the TEI XML; however, attributes need to be applied to the tables, rows, and cells manually (see for example the role="label" attributes found in the rows in the XML sample below). Also each table should be checked against the original DOCX to assure that there weren't any errors in the conversion process. So far there have note been many tables in 84000 publications but here is one example from TOH 361:

p.ref: (See how this example is displayed in reading room.)

div.p: As you can see a table contains an optional heading and a series of rows. Each row in turn contains a series of cells representing the way they are to be rendered from left to right. Add the very bottom of the table after the final row, any notes may be placed here regarding the table itself. In the example above there are three such notes marked by asterisks. These are not endnotes, as they do not have the place="end" attribute, so they will be rendered at the bottom of the table rather than becoming additional endnotes. Optionally, paragraphs p may be placed at the bottom of the table in a similar manner, still within the table but after the final row.

Currently there is no need to distinguish how the table should be rendered, but as this becomes necessary, any rendition information should be supplied using the global rend attribute, at the table, row, or cell level as appropriate. Currently no type is being used, but this may be added to the schema and documentation when it becomes necessary. Cells and rows should be assigned role="label" if they are considered to be the label or heading in which the subsequent cells are considered to be data relevant to that label. If a row contains the role="label" attribute, then all of its child cells will be considered to be "label"s as well. These labels will be rendered in bold type in the HTML web display.

Note, when marking up tables the markup editor should check that the table renders properly in the reading room's web display. In addition, the table needs to be checked in the ebook display as well. This can be done by adding the code: ?viewmode=epub to the very end of the url address on the utilities page. In truth, the tables are not compatible with the ebook format, so the parser will instead display them as a bulleted list. The information in this list should be presented in a complete and eloquently readable way, otherwise the parser should be updated.

div.head: Mantras
div.label: Documenting all mantras with mantra tags.
div.p: The tags used for mantras are a bit complicated because our final markup as it is found in the final XML needs to document all of the strings of mantra, but not all the mantra’s text will necessarily be italicized, as in some cases mantras will be translated into English with leftover fragments of foreign italicized terms in the form of seed syllables or untranslatable words (Hung! Phet! etc...). Therefore, as a general rule all mantras, whether in the main text or notes should be marked by a mantra tag, however, the italics will be determined by the parser according to the xml:lang attributes in the mantra element: if the value is "en" or "mixed" the mantra won't be italicized, but with any other language value all the text within the mantra tag will be italicized. In the case of a mixed translated English/Sanskrit mantra, the Sanskrit fragments within the parent mantra need to be additionally marked up with <foreign xml:lang="Sa-Ltn"> elements in order to render the italics. See examples below in "a. General Scenarios."
div.label: Tagging mantras with styles in MS Word
div.p: To help stream line this process the mantras will be partially marked up by styles converted from the copyeditor template in MS Word, however because MS Word can't layer multiple character styles, we can't tag the foreign fragments and the mantras at the same time. To resolve this conundrum, we have come up with the following solution: If the mantra is full and complete in one language, it can be tagged with the appropriate style in the template, but if the mantra is mixed, then just the italicized fragments should be tagged with a "Fragment-in-MixedMantra" style. This will in turn create a foreign element that contains a type="FragmentinMixedMantra" attribute. Then since "FragmentinMixedMantra" is not a valid type value in our schema it will show up as an error, which will signal you to wrap the whole mantra in a <mantra xml:lang="mixed"> tag. Finally after these mixed mantras have been wrapped in <mantra xml:lang="mixed"> tags from their beginning to end, all of the type="FragmentinMixedMantra" attributes can be removed with the refactoring tool: Within the Tools --> XML Refactoring tool, use the "Delete Attribute" opperation, then for element enter in: mantra/foreign[@type="FragmentinMixedMantra"] and for the attribute enter in: type This will insure that only the type attributes will be removed that have the value "FragmentinMixedMantra" and it will also only remove those of foreign elements within mantras, this way it will ensure that all of them have first been properly wrapped in <mantra xml:lang="mixed"> elements.
div.label: Placing some mantras in indented blocks.
div.p: In terms of style, whenever there is a formally declared mantra, it will often be placed into an indented block paragraph. This is not configured by the mantra tag, but rather by adding a rend="mantra" attribute to the parent p or lg element which is to be rendered as an indented block by the parser. However, this will not always the case, depending on the length, frequency, and context of the mantra, the translator and/or copy editors may wish to place the mantras in regular paragraphs or verses. This is a stylistic choice that will vary from case to case. All of the rend="mantra" attributes will be created by the script wherever the "Mantra-Block" or "Mantra-Block-Verse" paragraph style is used within the copyeditor's template. So in general, this will be dealt with in the copyediting phase and markup editors will not need to apply these rend attributes, but you should be aware how this markup works.
div.label: Dhāraṇis and seed syllables.
div.p: Seed syllables that are mentioned in the text for the purposes of visualization or explanation should also be marked up as mantras, but they need to be distinguished with the type="syllable" attribute (see example below a.iv).

For all dhāraṇis, that is if a string or phrase is declared to be a dhāraṇi by either the text itself or the translator, then these should be tagged in the same way, but a type="dharani" attribute should be added to the mantra element. Currently "dhāraṇi" styles have not been added to the template, instead copy editors are informed to make a comment whenever dharanis are present. The markup editor need to add the appropriate type="dharani" so be sure to keep an eye out for this while going through the mantras in the XML. There are also some mantras self described as "vidyā", "vidyāmantra", "secret mantra", etc. in some texts (see Toh 270, 543) which can be tagged in the same way.
See below examples for all the scenarios in which mantra markup occurs and how to properly mark them up:
div.label: a. General Scenarios:

item.p: i. When the complete mantra in Sanskrit is contained in the main text:

lg.l: “There are mantra syllables for this,
So please listen to me, Lord of the World!

item.p:
*mantra tag will be italicized by parser.
*rend attribute in the parent p or lg will determine if the mantra is indented as a block.

item.p: ii. When there is mixed translated English/Sanskrit mantra with a note that contains the complete mantra in Sanskrit:

lg.l: “In the east, ‘ Oṁ, bring downfall! Pātanī, svāhā to you!’ Skt., oṁ pāta pātanīsvāhā.

item.p:
*Mixed mantra is placed in <mantra xml:lang="mixed"> tags (need to be applied by markup editor since MS Word can't double wrap tags).
*Note, the language values that are included in xml:lang=“mixed” are all declared by its child foreign elements with the exception of the default “en” English.
*Italics will be determined by the foreign tags and not the parent mantra tag.
*Any left over type="FragmentinMixedMantra" tags are to be removed with the refactoring tool after completing mantra markup.

item.p: iii. When the complete mantra in Skt is contained in the text and spans notes:

egXML.l: On the eyes, oṁ tuttāre The Degé (90a.3) has ture (tu re) in this position. svāhā.

item.p: *Note, When a fragment of a mantra is mentioned in a note quoting an alternate source, do not use a use a mantra elment instead use a <foreign type="quote">. However if it is a complete mantra within the note then the mantra element should be used.

item.p: iv. A syllable referred to in isolation in the text:

lg.l: “He should visualize a sun disk
With blazing light rays,
And at its center the syllable hrīḥ,
Shining with red light. {2.4.15}

p.ref: (See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room).

item.p: note. In general, with English/mixed mantras we should include the final period or exclamation mark within the tag, as the mantra is usually a complete sentence and sometimes spans more than one sentences so it makes sense to include them for consistency. However, if the mantra is entirely in Sanskrit, then this punctuation should be excluded if possible. Quotations at the boundaries of the mantra should be excluded from the tag wherever possible.

div.label: e. Blocking glossary terms from linking to Sanskrit/foreign mantras.
div.p: Optionally a @rend="ignoreGlossary" attribut may be added to any mantra element. Typically we want to do this for any Mantra left in untranslated Sanskrit since the complex spelling declinations will cause the terms to be linked inconsistently. However it is likely appropriate to leave such terms linked when the mantra has been translated into English. Know that in either case, @rend="ignoreGlossary" will block the entire mantra from linking; or terms can instead be blocked individually by adding <term type="ignore"> tags.
div.label: f. Regarding Homages
div.p: Typically, the homage preceding just before a mantra should not be included in the mantra tag nor the indented paragraph. This can sometimes be confusing since separate homages sometimes appear as part of the mantra proper. All of this should be worked out earlier in the workflow by the editors and copy editors, but in case you need to confirm this, here are some guidelines concerning the mantras and their homages given by Wiesiek Mical:
Most of the time there is no ambiguity. There are three things to look for when deciding whether the homage is part of the mantra or not, each of the three usually sufficient on its own to decide:

list.item:
1) The presence of tadyathā. If it is there, then the homage that precedes it is not part of the mantra, as in this mantra of Mahāśvetā (all examples quoted below are from the Mañjuśrīmūlakalpa):
Sanskrit Source:
namaḥ samantabuddhānām acintyādbhutarūpiṇām / tadyathā / oṁ śvete śrīvapuḥ svāhā //
In Translation:
Homage to all the buddhas whose forms are wondrous and inconceivable! The [vidyā] is:
<mantra>Oṁ, you with the white splendorous body! Svāhā!</mantra>
“Homage to all the buddhas,
Whose forms are wondrous and inconceivable!
The next vidyā is:
“ Oṁ, you with the white, splendorous body! Svāhā!
See in Reading Room

2) But the tadyathā is not always there, as in this heart mantra of Mañjuśrī:
Sanskrit Source
namaḥ sarvabuddhānām / oṁ maṁ //
In Translation
“Homage be to all the buddhas!
<mantra>Oṁ maṁ!</mantra>
“Homage to all the buddhas!
“Oṁ maṁ!”
See in Reading Room
It is almost a rule (exceptions are few) that the homage begins with namaḥ, and the mantra that follows it begins with oṁ, so the oṁ will usually marks the beginning of the mantra.

3) The third criterion to go by is that the homage addresses the buddhas (or the buddhas and bodhisattvas) in general, whereas the mantra addresses the deity—both examples given above make this clear, even though, in the second, Mañjuśrī is not addressed by name.
The above three criteria may be used to decide that the homage is not part of the mantra. So how to know when the homage is part of the mantra?
The main criterion is that the homage in such cases will typically begin with oṁ and address specifically the deity of the mantra (not the buddhas in general). This is illustrated by the example quoted by Celso—Oṁ, homage to Cakravartin, the invincible uṣṇīṣa of the tathāgatas, invisible at the top of their head, (oṁ namo • apratihata­tathāgatoṣṇīṣāya • anavalokita­mūrdhni cakra­varti)—where the homage addresses the uṣṇīṣa king Cakravartin, i.e. the deity that this mantra is invoking. The homage is therefore part of the mantra.
Even if the oṁ is missing (due to textual corruptions?), if the homage specifically addresses the deity, it still should be treated as part of the mantra:
Sanskrit Source
namo bhagavate • apratihatoṣṇīṣāya / ehi ehi bhagavan dharmarāja / pratīccheyam arghyaṃ… //
In Translation
<mantra>Homage to the blessed, invincible uṣṇīṣa! Come, come, o blessed Dharma lord! Take this welcome-offering… </mantra>
“Homage to the blessed, invincible uṣṇīṣa! Come, come, O blessed Dharma lord! Take this welcome offering of water, fragrances, flowers, incense, refreshments, and lamps, and protect me! Svāhā to you, one of invincible strength and power!
See in Reading Room
Also, there are innumerable mantras that consist entirely of homage. In these cases, the presence or absence of oṁ is often the only differentiator between a mantra and just homage. For example, oṁ namaḥ śivāya is a mantra, and namaḥ śivāya on its own would by just homage.

Ellipses: Ellipses are to be made with three periods and non-breaking spaces (U+00A0) before each of the periods. It will look like this: watch out for . . . the rabbit, however please do not copy and paste the ellipsis from here, there is a problem with this ODD being transferred into the readable HTML format, and so the non-breaking spaces have been changed to regular ones. Instead, you may copy the ellipsis from this text file saved on google drive (Don't open the file from Google docs, this will also change them into regular spaces). When you paste the ellipsis into the TEI and place the cursor in front of each space the first three spaces should all be non-breaking and it will display "U+00A0" in the bottom right corner of the Oxygen window. Note that the fourth space after the last period should be a regular space (U+0020) so it is still possible to have a break before the next word. Ellipses should be entered in this format by the copyeditors, they will be carried through the scripts so you shouldn't worry about them unless you notice that they were entered in an improper format. In Oxygen, if you place the cursor before any space or character it will show you the unicode at the bottom of the screen. If you need to correct any ellipses paste them in from the text file.
Soft Hyphen: See guidelines for soft hyphens in Appendix E.

div.head: Abbreviations Section
div.p: As for when Kangyur abbreviations should be used here is a note from John:
I see this as needing an adapted approach, depending on the number and kind of notes, in several steps:

list.item: 1) I think in texts where there aren’t many notes about variants in different Kangyurs — let’s say a maximum of about 10 notes — it's probably easier for our readers if we simply spell out “Degé Kangyur” or “Stok Palace Kangyur” each time.

2) If there are more notes than that, but they almost all refer to one Kangyur, we could say “Degé Kangyur” the first time and just “Degé” in subsequent mentions, and an abbreviations list is unnecessary.

3) If there are quite a lot of notes and they refer to several different Kangyurs, or the Chinese, Sanskrit versions, etc., then we should definitely have an abbreviations list and use the sigla alone in all such notes.

div.p: This should be covered by the editors, but they may not have created an abbreviations section. If there are a lot for sigla used in the notes (situation 3 above), but there is not abbreviations section, then please create one modeled on other texts.
When the abbreviations for alternative Kangyur editions are used, you should follow the Vienna system.
Sigla with supscript letters should use the <hi rend="subscript"> tag, using the matching case used in the official sigla, e.g., KY .

div.head: Appendices: Sanskrit and Other Appendices
div.p: The headings, head, are used in the same manner as within the body of the text, and use the same possible @type attributes as is appropriate to the content, e.g., "prologue", "chapter", "section", etc.

The headings will appear in the table of contents and should be clearly labeled according to what they are ("Sanskrit Text", "An Outline of the Present Day Ordination Rite", etc.) so they can be easily found and referenced by the reader from the table of contents.
Here is an example from Toh 381:

p.ref: See Toh 381 in Reading Room.

list.item: If it is a Sanskrit Appendix the initial heading should be labeled "Sanskrit Text" and then any sub headings may be labeled appropriately as chapters, sections, etc.
To distinguish between the numbers in the appendix's chapter headers from those in the main translation add an "-A" to each number, e.g., "Chapter A1", "Chapter A2"...

Often the translator will have typed untagged milestones into the Sanskrit appendices. If possible we would like to arrange our own milestones so that the milestone index generated in the reading room by the parser match up with these, and then the original milestones from the word doc may be commented out. For example see Toh 437, and if you look in the original TEI you will see the orginal milestones in the appendix have been commented out. However, there are some cases when this will not be possible because some complexity in the correlation. This was the case in Toh 543 where the text was translated from a Sanskrit manuscript in which chapters omitted in the Tibetan were skipped. In this case the final milestones were left in as is, and an explanation was added in the appendix's prologue.

Note, that often there will be entries in the glossary that may be Sanskrit names or terms that also appear in the Sanskrit appendix. However since these won't be linked consistently due to Sanskrit's complex spelling declinations, we generally want to avoid linking the Sanskrit body of the appendices all together. This can be done by adding an @rend="ignoreGlossary" attribute to either the p or div elements you would like to be blocked. Ostensibly there will be terms in the English prologue/introduction to the appendix that we would won't to link, so these @rend attributes can be applied and adjusted according to the need.

div.head: Guidelines for Glossary:
Some Notes About How the Glossary Works
div.p: Note, also see the Translator Guidelines V.G. Glossary. There is a definitive explanation for translators on how to create their glossaries and these principles should be carried forward in to markup.
div.label: How Reader Handles Plurals:
div.p: A term will be matched if it is followed by s, es, 's, or s' and then a non-word character, e.g. Maitreya, Maitreya's, Maitreyas. (Unfortunately, the general marker for non-word characters is not Sanskrit-aware. It handles Sanskrit diacritic characters as non-word characters. While we have handled most of the related issues in this case it can result in a few mistakes, e.g. Maitreyasāyana).
div.label: Capitalization
div.p: The glossary is not case-sensitive and will link to names and terms regardless of capitalization. However, note that as a standard within the TEI proper names should be capitalized in the English and Sanskrit field but NOT in the Tibetan Wylie field. Although the parser will display all the English and Sanskrit entries in the Reading Room itself as capitalized regardless of the text found in the TEI.
div.label: Use of the term Tag to Mark the Same Word Used in Different Ways:
div.p: Sometimes we will only want certain instances of a string of text to be marked as a glossary term. For example, perhaps we want the term "appropriate" to be linked to this term when it is used as verb but not when it used as an adjective. The translator guidelines [G4] instructs translators to flag instances of glossary terms that are only relevant to specific passages with the “†” symbol. They are also instructed to specify glossary entries as verbs (vb), nouns (n), or adjectives (adj) in cases where the glossary entry is only intended to link to one form of the word and not others, for example "play" or "appropriate" (These should not be left in the text but replaced with the markup described in the following section). However, many of these may be missed and so all the linked terms should be checked in markup. Note, that we are no longer using zero-width-non-joiners to resolve this issue. Instead, we now use the "mode" attribute within the gloss element.

In the glossary, gloss nodes can be given the attributes mode="match|marked." Match mode will highlight any matches in the text except where they have been marked up with term type="ignore", e.g.: parse this but not this Marked mode will only match terms that have been marked up with term e.g. Ignore this but match this.
div.label: How Tibetan Is Created from Wylie:
div.p: Where a glossary item has a Wylie term but no Tibetan the database will auto-generate the Tibetan. To re-create a Tibetan term simply remove the node, save, and refresh. The Wylie string will also have a trailing space enforced. These will produce the respective syllable separators in the Tibetan. Double underscores in Wylie will be replaced with a single space when output to the reader.

If later you make a correction to a Tibetan entry, be sure to delete the term with Tibetan Unicode (the one with xml:lang="bo") this will trigger the database to auto-generate a new one from the corrected Wylie entry, but if you leave it as is the error will remain in the Tibetan Unicode.
div.label: Links to Paragraphs with Instances:
div.p: The reader lists links to each paragraph that includes instances of a glossary term.
div.label: For Multiple Tibetan and Sanskrit Forms of Spelling for a Single Term:
div.p: In some cases a single gloss entry may have multiple forms for spelling the Tibetan, the Sanskrit, or both. In this case each spelling of the term can be listed separately in its own term element. However, Tibetan should be listed first, followed by the Sanskrit, as in the following example for the term "karnikara" (note that a Tibetan "bo" term is auto-generated after each instance of Tibetan Wylie "Bo-Ltn"):

gloss.term: Pterospermum acerifolium. Other names include bayur, muchakunda, muchalinda, and dinner-plate tree.

p.ref: (See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room).

div.p: Note that in the example above, these spelling variations are supplied by the author but don't actually appear in the translated text. If there are alternative spellings of a term within the text itself, they need to be marked as type="alternative."
div.label: Use of Alternatives in the Glossary Entry:
div.p: Glossary items can also include term type="alternative" nodes to specify other variations in the spelling that should be marked in the text:

p.ref: (See in the Reading Room; note that the alternative term isn't listed in the glossary but is linked in the text as the third occurrence).

div.p:
Alternatives may be added for any related terms that should be linked to the entry such as:
When a plural "-s" appears in the middle of the string in certain cases and is not linking (as in the XML example above), or not linking because the plural has an irregular spelling, e.g. "phenomena" and "phenomenon"; "birth-story" and "birth-stories"; etc...
Alternate nominal or verbal uses of the same term: appropriate, appropriated, appropriation.
Extended names such as "Mañjuśrī" and "Mañjuśrī the crown prince". In this last case only if the simple name is clearly represented in the extended one, otherwise a second gloss should be added referring to the primary one, e.g.: The Great Compassionate One -- See Avalokiteśvara.

However, alternatives should not be used for two semantically different English words, even if they are translated from the same Tibetan term and have similar meaning. For example if "offering" and "worship" are both used for "mchod pa / pūjā". They should be given two different glossary entries.
The 84000 translator's guidelines (G4) states this clearly:

If the same Tibetan or Sanskrit word was translated in more than one way, include an entry for each, and place in the definition a reference to the other rendering, e.g. for the entry “Offering” (mchod pa / pūjā): “Also translated here as ‘worship,’ ” (and vice versa for the entry “Worship”).

There are two reasons for this. (1) We don't want readers unfamiliar with Tibetan and Sanskrit clicking on a term like "worship" and having it link to "offering," and (2) Some readers may be reading the text in a PDF format or even someday in print and will need to look up terms alphabetically as the hyperlinks won't be available.

Some of these alternatives may have been entered improperly and will need to be separated into separate entries. This should be handled by copy editors, but in some cases it may be missed and markup editors will be more capable of spotting inconsistencies or issues in the glossary since they will be able to actually click on the links and check them in the Reading Room.

There has been some further discussion regarding whether alternatives should be used when the English words for a glossary entry are used in a different word order. So in the example above for "door of the dharma" one might ask, should this itself be used as an alternative linking to the entry for "dharma-door" or should it be in a separate entry? In this case it isn't such an issue that the reader would click on "door of the Dharma" and see the entry for "Dharma-door" but it is an issue for anyone reading the PDF. However it is quite sensible that the reader would simply search for the term under "dharma" if they did not find it in "door". If there are a just a few instances of these it makes sense to create separate entries, but if the amount of entries with alternate word order is becoming extensive then this could be an issue because it will muddy up the glossary, be difficult for reader to find all the instances of a term from the "passages contain this term" field, and also it could muddy up the cumulative glossary. When there are a lot of such alternatives it may be better to set such phrases as "door of the dharma" as an alternative provided that it would be sensible from the perspective of the reader and there aren't semantically distinct words (e.g., you wouldn't want to add "gateway of the dharma" as an alternative). If there are a lot of such instances, you should also check with the editors about changing the translation to be more consistent (make notes about such instances in the Reading Room Worksheet). This should be taken on a case by case basis and always thought of from the readers perspective.
div.label: Further Explanation on the Mode Attribute:
div.p: The mode attribute is not required, but when present it can either be "match" or "marked." "Match" is the default (where this attribute is not specified). "Match" will behave in the normal way: the text is scanned for glossary matches and highlighted accordingly.
"Marked," on the other hand, will only consider text strings that have been marked up with term. An example for "appropriate" is below:

egXML.p: Bhadrapāla said, “Blessed One, sentient beings in this world do not know about their consciousness. If not understanding consciousness is akin to not knowing of a jewel hidden in a box, what then, Blessed One, is consciousness? Why is it called consciousness? Blessed One, a dying person’s limbs and eyes fail; when, at the moment of death, his faculties cease and he loses his constituent elements, how does this consciousness undergo transfer from the body, and what type of form does it have? What is its nature? How does it separate from the body? How does consciousness, after abandoning one body, appropriate another body? After abandoning the elements and casting off the sensory fields, how does it leave this world and go on to the next? How does it appropriate different bodies? Blessed One, how do a dying person’s sensory fields follow him? Blessed One, how does someone experience, in another world, the roots of virtue accumulated in this world? How is it that the roots of virtue accumulated by the current aggregates are experienced later on by another set of aggregates? How does consciousness follow the body? How do the sensory fields follow the body?”

p.ref: (See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room).

div.label: Linking terms in the body of the text to the glossary entry directly with the @ref attribute.
div.p: Sometimes, if there are three or more glossary entries with the same exact string, the marked application alone will not be sufficient. In this case the duplicate gloss entries should all be tagged mode="marked" and the terms within the body of the text may be linked directly to the proper glossary entry by adding a @ref attribute that points that term to the specific entry attributed to it. For example there are three separate entries for the name "Upananda" in Toh 340. These may be distinguished in the text as follows:

egXML.p: He had come to Śrāvastī very late, and seeing that the other monks had already gone carrying their alms bowls filled, he thought, “I will ask where I should go to quickly get some alms.” So he went to see Upananda and asked him,
King Prasenajit implored the Blessed One, “Lord, the Blessed One has tamed vicious nāgas like Nanda, Upananda,
“Now the king had two wise chief ministers, capable, clear-minded, trustworthy, shrewd, disciplined, and prudent. Their names were Nanda and Upananda.

gloss.term: A member of the Śākya clan and monk of the Buddha’s order, he often appears in the vinaya texts, as here, to exemplify certain wrong behaviors.
Not to be confused with Upananda, one of King Mahā­deva's ministers; or with Upananda, the nāga.
Along with Nanda, one of King Mahadeva’s two chief ministers in the city of Mithilā.
The name of a certain nāga.
Not to be confused with “Upananda,” one of King Mahā­deva's ministers; or with Upananda, the monk.

p.ref: See this example in Reading Room.

div.p: ***Important Note: if you use a @ref to mark a terms to a glossary entry with mode="marked", be sure to also add @refs to any terms that need to be linked to the other mode="marked" entry(s) otherwise the parser may link all marked terms without @refs to the first mode="marked" entry. So as in the example above, instances of both Upananda the minister and nāga need to be marked with term elements with @refs, but Upananda the monk may be left as is because the first entry isn't mode="marked"
div.label: Blocking the glossary from linking to entire paragraphs, stanzas, divisions, or mantras
div.p: Optionally an @rend="ignoreGlossary" attribute may be added to any p, lg, div, or mantra element to block all the text within from linking to the glossary. Typically we want to do this for Sanskrit appendices, long Sanskrit quotes, or mantras where the complex Sanskrit spelling declinations will cause terms to be linked inconsistently. Note, the @rend="ignoreGlossary" attribute can ostensibly be used on any element in the TEI document although the schema may need to be updated to validate it in particular cases. Email the ODD editor (Celso) if the schema needs to be updated.
div.label: Some Final Tips for Polishing the Glossary:

list.item: Sometimes a term will appear in its own definition. In this case it looks a bit silly for the term to link to itself, so it would be best to mark it with term type="ignore".
If there are references in the definition to a term, such as "see also...", they can be placed into a second term type="definition" line, to create some visual lightness in the final webdisplay.

If a word is not linking in the webdisplay, here are some common causes for instances not being detected by the parser:
Plurals in the middle of strings of words (where the "s" doesn't come at the end).
An extra space at the end of the term in the glossary.
Sanskrit soft-hypens in the term not matching with the glossary entry.

Occasionally you will see a word in the text that is similar to a glossary term but isn't linked because it takes as different form. For instance, "appropriate" is in the glossary, but you see "appropriation" in the text. If you see instances like this you can add an term type="alternative" to that gloss item, but be sure that you are not then linking to other unwanted instances as well.

div.head: Guidelines for Entering Milestones into the TEI Document
div.p: Milestones are applied to the document with the “milestone unit="chunk"/” tag. Because the 84000 reading room does not have page numbers, milestones are particularly important for referencing sections or paragraphs in the text.

Milestones should be applied to the text at places where there is a logical/thematic division in the text. Sometimes, milestones can be placed at the beginning of each paragraph of prose. In cases where paragraphs are very short (only one or two sentences) milestones can be placed one for every two or more paragraphs depending on the context, or a particularly short paragraph can share the milestone with that of a larger previous or later paragraph that shares the same “theme.”

To a large degree the editor should use their own judgment: If the milestones are too frequent, then it will become distracting to the reader on the page. If they are too far apart, it will be difficult to cite particular passages of the text. It is helpful to check the display in the reading room after applying milestones to make sure they appear in a convenient way and to visually check there is general consistency throughout the text.

Often there will be very short paragraphs used during sections of dialogue. A logical way to organize these sections is to allow one question and answer to be given a single milestone. For example, the following passage could be given one milestone:

egXML.p: The Lord then said to the venerable Śāriputra, “Śāriputra, did you see that universe Abhirati, and the Tathāgata Akṣobhya?”

Śāriputra replied, “I saw it, Lord! May all living beings come to live in a buddhafield as splendid as that! May all living beings come to have miraculous powers just like those of the noble Licchavi Vimalakīrti!

p.ref: (See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room).

div.p: If either the question or the answer are very short paragraphs (one or two sentences), then they could be appended to the milestone along with their respective question and answer. However, if both the question and answer are long paragraphs in themselves, they should each be given their own milestone. Of course, there will always be unique situations such as questions being answered with another question and so forth. The editor should in general use their own discretion to decide what frequency of milestones would be the most useful and least distracting to the reader. They should to try to be consistent with their usage.

When entering milestones for lines of verse, the editor should apply milestones in a consistent manner, which will typically be one milestone marker between every line group element lg. Usually this will be a verse of four lines in English.
For example, see how milestones are applied to the following verses from The Teachings of Vimalakīrti:

lg.l: Pure are your eyes, broad and beautiful, like the petals of a blue lotus.
Pure is your thought, having discovered the supreme transcendence of all trances.
Immeasurable is the ocean of your virtues, the accumulation of your good deeds.
You affirm the path of peace. O Great Ascetic, obeisance to you!
Leader, bull of men, we behold the revelation of your miracle.
The superb and radiant fields of the sugatas appear before us,
And your extensive spiritual teachings, that lead to immortality
Make themselves heard throughout the whole reach of space.
Dharma-King, you rule with the Dharma your supreme Dharma-kingdom,
And thereby bestow the treasures of the Dharma upon all living beings.
Expert in the deep analysis of things, you teach their ultimate meaning.
Sovereign Lord of Dharma, obeisance to you!

p.ref: (See example in reading room.)

div.p: One exception to this may occur when a set of verses are introduced by a very short line, such as “The Blessed One said:” In this case use your judgment to place a milestone either before this short line and not the verse, or vice-versa, depending on the spatial and thematic context you are working in:

egXML.p: When the Blessed One had explained the meaning to them, he spoke these verses:

lg.l: “Some say that what is created is compounded,
While others say that it is uncompounded.
However, as both apprehend phenomena, both are concepts.
Such conceptual elaborations are called impure.
“Phenomena are not created by anyone, nor does anything destroy them.
No one sees them, knows them, or is close to them.
Such untenable domains of imputed thought—
All are designated empty.

p.ref: (See example in reading room.)

div.p: In another case the editor may encounter short sentences used in a debate-like dialogue. For example, in this following dialogue found in The Teachings of Vimalakīrti:

egXML.p: Mañjuśrī: What is the great compassion of a bodhisattva ?
Vimalakīrti: It is the giving of all accumulated roots of virtue to all living beings.
Mañjuśrī: What is the great joy of the bodhisattva?
Vimalakīrti: It is to be joyful and without regret in giving.
Mañjuśrī: What is the equanimity of the bodhisattva?
Vimalakīrti: It is what benefits both self and others.
Mañjuśrī: To what should one resort when terrified by fear of life?
Vimalakīrti: Mañjuśrī, a bodhisattva who is terrified by fear of life should resort to the magnanimity of the Buddha.

p.ref: (See example in reading room.)

div.p: A similar passage in The Absorption of the Thus-Gone One’s Wisdom Seal:

egXML.p: “Blessed One, to what do the terms unchanging and nonconceptual refer?”
“Noble sons, unchanging and nonconceptual refer to nonreferential.”
“Blessed One, to what does nonreferential refer?”
“Noble sons, nonreferential refers to inexhaustible.”
“Blessed One, to what does inexhaustible refer?”
“Noble sons, inexhaustible refers to unborn.”
“Blessed One, to what does unborn refer?”
“Noble sons, unborn refers to uninterrupted.”

p.ref: (See example in reading room.)

egXML.p: “A bodhisattva’s buddhafield is a field of virtuous application. When he attains enlightenment, living beings who live by all virtuous principles will be born in his buddhafield.

“A bodhisattva’s buddhafield is the magnificence of the conception of the spirit of enlightenment. When he attains enlightenment, living beings who are actually participating in the Mahāyāna will be born in his buddhafield.
“A bodhisattva’s buddhafield is a field of generosity. When he attains enlightenment, living beings who give away all their possessions will be born in his buddhafield.
“A bodhisattva’s buddhafield is a field of morality. When he attains enlightenment, living beings who follow the path of the ten virtues with positive thoughts will be born in his buddhafield.

p.ref: (See example in reading room.)

div.p: Here the editor might place a milestone for each item in the list depending on the length of each paragraph. It might also be appropriate to place the milestones according to logical groupings in the list, for example place one milestone for the four immeasurables, one milestone for the six paramitas, etc. Finally, if the list becomes overburdened by milestones, the editor can add the milestones for every two or four items in the list. In this case it might be worthwhile to check how many items there are in the list then seek a reasonable way to divide it up evenly.

If the editor is not sure about the frequency for applying milestones, he or she can refer to some of the other texts in the reader and see how frequently the milestones are used in other texts. For now, Toh 131 is a good example.

While editing in oXygen, it can be easier to edit milestones while in "author mode" (go to "Author" in the menu bar and click on "Switch to Author Mode." This will show the layout of the text more clearly and you can remove the milestones by double clicking on them and hitting delete.) This is a useful way to quickly edit milestones, but should not be a substitute for checking visually in the Reading Room.

There are a few places where we always want to have a milestone: (1) trailers (both at the end of chapters and any concluding trailer to the entire text); (2) the opening homage and the following paragraph; and (3) in ancillary sections (summary, acknowledgement, colophon, etc.).

div.head: Guidelines for Entering Soft Hyphens to Sanskrit
div.p: Note that only editors with a basic understanding of the spelling and sandhi rules of Sanskrit should proceed with this step. You don't need to be an expert in Sanskrit, as most words can be looked up in online references, however, for this step editors will need to have a clear grasp on how the sandhi rules in Sanskrit work. If not please request that another editor with this skill to complete this task.

list.item: Look for long Sanskrit chains, and add optional soft-hyphens at points where there are chains that are 15+ characters long. Optional soft-hyphens are created with the character code: ­Note that after you save the XML these will look like regular hyphens, but if you move the blinking cursor to the space just before the hyphen you will notice there is a different character code displayed at the bottom of the oXygen screen.

The long Sanskrit chains can be found easily by going to Window > Show View > XPath/XQuery Builder, then in the XPath/XQuery Builder window type the following code and press the red play button://*[string-length(string()) > 14 and @xml:lang ='Sa-Ltn'] You can save this query for later by clicking on the star and choosing "add to favourites."

Note that texts that have Sanskrit appendixes will not be checked by the code above because these sections aren't marked with an @xml:lang attribute. Generally, the Sanskrit appendixes such as the one in Toh 437 does not need soft hyphens because it is not anticipated that they will be read on small devices. However, occasionally there may be extremely long strings in the appendices that will fill the screen even on a regular web browser. For the appendices our current limit is any strings longer than 40 continuous characters without as space. To search the appendices, press CTRL/SHIFT/H to "search in files" then check the "regular expression" box, in the scope select "All open files", and in "Restrict to XPath:" enter the code: //text(). Finally, in the search field enter the following regex code: (^|\s|-­)[^\s-­]{40,}($|\s|-­). This should give you a list of all the 40+ strings while ignoring tags, spaces, or hyphens.

Be careful when adding the soft hyphens as they should only be placed at certain points in the words where they do not interfere with the Sanskrit rules of sandhi. When adding the soft hyphens please follow the following guidelines:

item.label: Guidelines for Adding Soft-Hyphens to Sanskrit:

item.p: 1. As we are not using full justification anyway, (a) most Sanskrit words don’t need hyphenation unless they are longer than 5 or 6 syllables, but (b) may be necessary for shorter words especially in text titles on the title page. I therefore tend to place soft hyphens in all of the text titles, in verse passages, in the bibliography entries, and in notes and glossary entries (which require shorter lines in general).

2. Place a soft hyphen (a) only between the words of a compound; (b) even then only when there are no changes brought about by sandhi (because putting a hyphen would logically mean undoing the sandhi, and the hyphens we’re talking about may or may not appear); and (c) avoiding confusing remnants.
A couple of examples:

Ratnagotravibhāgottaratantraśāstra would be Ratna-gotra-vibhāgottara-tantra-śāstra. If we divided the 5-syllable sequence in the middle, that would have to undo the sandhi and become -vibhāga-uttara-, which only works in the presence of a hard hyphen. Theoretically we could put a hyphen at vi-bhāga, but that would risk leaving us with -gotravi-, which would be potentially confusing to read.

The maximum we could hyphenate antānantaḍṛṣṭivāsanābhisaṃdhisamuccedaka would be antānanta-ḍṛṣṭi-vāsanābhi-saṃdhi-sam-ucchedaka, because antānanta and vāsanābhi-saṃdhi would become anta-ananta and vāsana-abhi-saṃdhi. In a case like that, I would also prefer to avoid ending up with antānantaḍṛṣṭivāsanābhi-saṃdhisamuccedaka, because the abhi- really belongs with the saṃdhi; it’s a possible break but is confusing to read.

list.item: One resource that is helpful for determining the breaks in Sanskrit chains in the online Cologne Sanskrit Dictionary. This one is really helpful because it has a drop down menu of similarly spelled words when you hit the enter key, however, I think this only works when you use the Kyoto-Harvard Transliteration scheme "KH." You might try the other ones but I found that this is the only one that gave the drop down list for me. Then when you find a big word in the dictionary in the definition entry you will see * whenever there is sandhi, though this isn't 100% reliable. Sometimes it is missing for some reason, so be careful if the spelling looks weird.

In certain cases there may be long 15+ Sanskrit chains that cannot be broken due to the sandhi, or long Sanskrit compounds whose pieces cannot be easily determined with online resources. If this is the case make a list of problematic instances to note for the leading editors, and also check these instances to see if the pose any major difficultly for the web display. These instances are rare, but they do come up now and then.
It is acceptable to add an optional hyphen at the end of "mahā-" as in "mahā-yāna" even though technically the long ā would be lost, as this is a well known word and unlikely to be misread.

Note that when you add the optional hyphens to a glossary item where the translation uses the Sanskrit (This will mainly be in the “Persons” and “Places” section of the glossary) the hyphens will have to match all those instances within the body of the text or they will not link to the glossary term, so it is best to start from the glossary and work your way backwards. For all of these person and place terms do a search and replace so that the hyphens match in all the instances of that term (be cautious when doing large search-and-replaces that you don’t make any unintended changes).
