div.head: Guidelines and Checklist for Updating the Schema and ODD
div.p: Note that updating the schema and ODD is a bit more complicated, so this should be handled by the lead editors or technicians. Otherwise, if you are working on a markup and notice that the schema needs to be updated (i.e., there is some markup needed but you are getting a schema error for that markup), then make this a point to send to the lead editors in your final list of questions and issues for finalizing the text. Please disregard the following instructions unless you are a lead editor or technician.

list.item: This appendix gives a brief explanation and checklist for how to update the ODD. However, you may need to refer to the 22nd chapter of the TEI guidelines for a more detailed explanation on how the elements in the ODD work. You may also need to refer to the 23rd chapter of the TEI guidelines which contains information on the content models, attribute customizations, and TEI conformance.

Most of the restrictions in the ODD are defined in the element specifications. In order to create documentation, an elementSpec has been created for all of the elements we use. There are also some schema restrictions defined in class specifications, classSpec, and macro specifications, macroSpec. In our ODD's XML the classSpecs are listed first followed by the macroSpecs followed by the elementSpecs all in alphabetical order. If you need to jump to a specific element, they can easily be found by searching for their ident attribute. For example, to find the elementSpec for the "front", search for c ident="front" and this will take you to that section of the ODD.

Adding new elements will require creating a new elementSpec and adding it to the ODD. Adding or modifying attributes can be done in that specific element's attList. For example here is the attList for the title element:
classifies the title according to the TBRC typology. classifies the title according to the 84000 typology.
The attDef defines a particular attribute for title, along with a description desc. The valList defines what values are allowed in the "type" attribute. Since we don't use the default "xml:id" and "level" attributes in our titles they have been set to "delete" so they won't appear in our documentation. We want the "xml:lang" to be required for all titles so the usage has been set to "reg". More details should can be found in the TEI guidelines.

When a language needs to be added to the schema, the language list is actually found in the class specification for "att.global" that defines the "xml:lang" attribute. It should be added here so it will apply to all the elements that use "xml:lang". To find this section search for attDef ident="xml:lang"

Content Models: The structure for the schema--i.e., what elements are allowed to be nested in what elements--are contained in the ODD content models, content. Each element used in our TEI has a content model defined in its element specification, or if it isn't stated then the default TEI content model will be used when the schema is generated in from Oxgarage. You can look up the default content model in the appendix of the TEI Guidelines Because the 84000 schema is very restrictive, we use often directly use relax ng code within the ODD to define content models for the structure of the text. That is why you will see the prefix "rng:-" before many of the elements there. When the content model needs to be updated, that is the rules which govern how the elements are to be nested, look for the content element in the ODD for that element's elementSpec. If is a global rule for that element it will be found there. However, keep in mind if it is a rule specific to the order or structure found in the front, body, or back, then the content model will be found in those element's content models.

To avoid writing repetitive code, there are also some content models declared in the marcroSpec these may be referred to in other content models, which will look something like this:
In this example the rng element points to the content model of our basic paragraph. And if that needs to be updated in can be done so in the macroSpec for "paragraph".

Note there are also many descriptions, desc, as well as examples egXML contained in all the specifications. It is not required to update these for the generation of the schema, but when you make in update, it would be good to update these as well so that our documentation can be most up to date. Also consider whether an update is something that the markup editors need to be aware of during their work flow. If it is, please add some explanation and/or protocol for the markup editors in the "Checklist for 84000 TEI Markup Editors". This appendix is found in the back of the ODD.

Occasionally, we may add a new element to our schema that is already included in one of the standard TEI modules. Note, that these standard elements are all declared at the beginning of the ODD in the moduleRef. This happened to me, I couldn't figure out why the hi element wasn't validating even though it was declared in an elementSpec. The reason was I had assumed it was declared as a part of the "core" module, but had forgotten to add it to the list within the moduleRef.

If you can't figure out why an added element or attribute isn't validating properly for a schema update. A good technique is to paste that element into a TEI document apply the schema, and read the schema error message at the bottom of the oXygen window. It should tell you what the schema is expecting and based on that you can determine where and which content model needs to be updated. Also keep in mind that any element from the standard TEI modules will have the default content model if a new one isn't declared, so you may need to look up the element in the TEI guidelines to find its default content model as well as its other parameters.

To summarize here is a brief checklist for any updates for the ODD/schema.
1) Make any changes to the element that needs update in that elements elementSpec
2) Does this change need to be reflected in the content model? If so make the appropriate corrections to the content found within the elementSpecs for the teiHeader, front, body, back, or possibly one of the macroSpecs
3) Update examples, egXML and/or descriptions desc if needed.
4) Update the markup editor's checklist if needed.

div.head: Useful Tips for Using the oXygen XML Editor:

label.hi: Further Useful Tips for using the XPath/XQuery Builder

list.item: The Xpath/XQuery builder is a useful tool for searching for unwanted stuff in the glossaries like brackets, slashes and so on. To open, go to Window > Show View > XPath/XQuery Builder

For example to search for a bracket withing the glossary use the following code: //gloss/term[@xml:lang = 'Bo-Ltn'][contains(text(), "(")] The "(" at the end is what determines the bracket. Enter this into the XPath/XQuery Builder and press the play button to perform the search.

By using backslashes and element names you can also look for specific terms within particular elements, for example to search for a certain "word" within the note elements, you could use this code: //note[contains(data(), 'word')] Here 'word' is what you are looking for. // means search everywhere, //note means search everywhere for notes.
You can save your search codes for later by clicking on the star icon.
To learn more about XPath syntax and how it works. There is a good tutorial here.
Also this section of the tutorial here, explains some syntax, which you should be able to use with the XPath/XQuery Builder.

You may notice that when you search for certain phrases in the XML, the phrase may not be found in the "Find/Replace" dialog. This is because the search tool is very precise so it will not find phrases with two or more words that are separated by a line break unless you specify it to do so. One way around this is to use the "Find in files" (click the second smaller magnifying glass in the ribbon or CTRL/SHIFT/H). Then select "All opened files" (It will ask you to save before it searches) and make sure "Ignore white spaces" is checked ("Regular expressions" must be unchecked for it to work). It will then ignore the line breaks.

The method above doesn't work with regular expressions. If you need to search in this way with regular expressions, then try replacing the spaces in your code with: \s+, e.g. search "door of dharma" with "door\s+of\s+dharma"
On occasion you may want to search the XML while ignoring all the tags. To do this, again use "find in files" CTRL/Shift/H and in the field that says "Restrict to XPath;" enter the code //text()

This will ignore the tags in your search results. Note, it will ignore the tags but it can't search over tags if a tag appears in the middle of a searched phrase, so for instance it won't fine "vidyā being" in the XML for
vidyā being

div.head: Guidelines for Updating Versions of the TEI Document
div.p: The three digit version numbering (e.g., "v 1.2.1") we are using here refer respectively to "major", "minor", and "revision" changes to the text (This emulates software versioning standards).

Any changes in the third decimal relate to very minor textual updates that don't substantially affect the text (typos, minor markup/formatting consistencies, etc.). A change from 1.2.1 to 1.2.2 signals to the reader that there is no need to download it. Any change in the second decimal relates to a minor, but more significant changes within the text itself as well as to significant markup changes. For example, a missing stanza has been added, or a misspelled term has been corrected throughout the text. A change from 1.2.1 to 1.3.0 indicates that readers should download the latest version to have an improved version of the text. Any change in the first decimal would be a major change to the text, so 1.3.1 to 2.0.0. would be a clear sign that it should be downloaded.
To summarize:

list.item: Changes in the third decimal relate to very minor textual and markup changes, e.g., 1.3.4 to 1.3.5
Changes in the second decimal relate to minor, but more significant textual and markup changes, e.g., 1.3.4 to 1.4.0
Changes in first decimal relate to major text changes, e.g., 1.3.4 to 2.0.0

div.p: Most texts that have not been started in the translation process have no version number. When a text receives its first update it will change to
When markup is started, the text gets an initial version number:

From that point on, version numbers will increase every time editors feel it’s necessary as they work on the text. As noted before, changes made to the second decimal point are reserved for more significant textual and markup edits, and changes made to the third decimal point are reserved for minor textual and markup edits. Theoretically, a text could go through many versions before it is ready for publication, eg

label.hi: When updating the TEI to a published translation please use the following procedure:

list.item: (1) When you make changes to a text, first check that the latest version is on distribution. If not, notify Mike or John that you are making changes to the text and to not push it to distribution until you are finished. This way a text that you are working on won’t be pushed to distribution until it is ready. Even if it is a relatively minor update, it is important to let admin know in case they are in the middle of pushing the texts to the published distribution database, in which case the changes may be incomplete or even just the version number could be missed.
(2) Save your changes from Oxygen.

(3) If you changed any of the markup, run the automated tests on the individual file by clicking on "run tests" next to the text title from the Utilities page (Note: don't run the automated tests from the "tests" tab unless it is necessary to check all the texts, as this will uses up a lot of the server's resources). Correct any issues related to failing test results or inform tech (Dom) about any test updates that may be needed.

(4) Finally, after saving the TEI from Oxygen, the version number needs to be updated separately on the project management page. This is important to keep track of any changes we've made to the published text: From the project management page, find the text according to its "text status," then click on "edit headers." From here, update both the version number (as described in the guidelines above) and if necessary the version's date (entering for the date only a four digit year, e.g., "2019"). Note, the "Publication Date" refers to the date of the original publication, so please leave this unchanged. Please also add a brief note in the "Add a note about this version" field about what changes were made. Now, click the "Update" button. Updating the version number in this way will simultaneously update the editionStmt's version and date within the TEI file, upload the latest version to the Github repository, and generate the newest version of the eBook and PDF (this last part of the update only occurs if it is status="1").
(5) Inform the lead markup editor (Mike), so that the updated files may be moved from collaboration to distribution.

div.p:
Occasionally, global changes will need to be made for all the texts, usually performed with a script or a search-and-replace in the translations folder (By the way if you make global search-and-replaces to a folder be sure that Oxygen's "Make back of files with extension" box is unchecked, as this will cause problems in the database). Since it would be time consuming to update each text manually, please follow this protocol for updating the texts manually:
1.) Make the global change (using script or find and replace). Make sure that the operation has worked correctly.
2.) Ask tech (Dominic) to run a script to update version numbers and add a descriptive note.
3.) Take a snapshot to capture version history for git (This is on the Utilities page menu: "Make a Data Snapshot").
4.) Assess whether pdfs, epubs, and html need to be republished immediately. If so, then do it manually using utilities. If not, then wait for the next change that warrants a republishing of the text. Especially minor changes may not warrant updating all the publications as texts will be updated periodically, and the change will be added eventually.

Whenever you make changes to a published text, you should always change the version number from project management. When you start working on a text in markup use a version number beginning with 0.1.1. Generally, we don't need a versioning history while the text is in the markup process, however, if the markup for a text is particularly complex, e.g., it is a very large text, it includes attributes that require us to come up with new markup language, it includes a complex outline structure, etc., you should occasionally update the version (e.g., 0.1.2) from project management as you processes different stages of the markup. In such cases, it would also be a good idea to occasionally save a backup locally to your computer. This way we can track the text, and especially have a way of knowing what version it is in case something goes wrong (which does happen from time to time).

div.head: Guidelines for Checking Older Versions of the TEI Documents in the Github Repository:
div.p: Sometimes there may have been an edition or correction that was made in an earlier version of a TEI file that was made in error or for some other reason we need to check that changes that were made in an earlier version of a document. In such cases, all the older versions of the XML are saved as snapshots in 84000's Github repository. To check older versions of the TEI please follow these steps below:

head.hi: Read or Download Archived Files on Github

list.item: Go to the translations folder on 84000's Github repository using this link. You do not need a Github account to check the version history.
From there you will be able to navigate to the TEI file you need. The repository should have the same outline and structure as the TEI database we work from on Oxygen.
Once you navigated to the file you need click on the "History" button. This will take you to a new screen showing you a history of all the snapshots of the file, called "commits" on Github.

By clicking on each commit, it will show you all the additions and deletions that were made to the file at that time. The version number update should be close to the top of the page. From here, it is very convenient to see what changes have been made to the file for each version update.

Or you can simply download that version of the TEI file by first clicking on the three dots ... to the right of the file name of that version, click "view file", the new screen click on the "download" button. (Note that some browsers will just open the XML on a new page, so you might need to right-click "Save Link As..." to download the actual file.

div.p: All the older versions of the files should be here since the time we begin syncing this Github repository. Note that sometimes there may have been a few version updates before a commit, but there should be a record of all the differences between the version at the time of the commit and the previous one.

head.hi: View Archived TEI in the Reading Room Display

list.item: If needed, it is also possible to see how older versions of the TEI display in the Reading Room. First download the desired version of the TEI from Github following the instructions above.

From the database explorer go to the folder in Collaboration/db/apps/84000-data/archived/tei/reference, then right click on the folder and select "import files." Select the file from your computer that you downloaded from Github.

The following URL, with the Toh number entered into the TohXXX will load the archived file to the Reading Room on Collaboration: https://read.84000-translate.org/translation/tohXXX.html?archive-path=tei/reference
The suffix "?archive-path=tei/reference" will likely work with some of the other formats as well.
Note, there is currently an issue with this method; it doesn't work for Toh numbers's with a dash, e.g., "1-1"

div.p: There may also be some versions of antiquated formats in the repository, so if you don't see what you are looking for in the translations folder, you can also search in the main branch.

div.head: Reporting Typos or Errors in the eKangyur:
div.p: The eKangyur is typically very precise, but occasionally there may have been an error when they were inputting the text. If you suspect a typo in the eKangyur, please note it in the spread sheet here. This should not include errors in the original block print, which we will leave as is, but there may have been an error in the text input of the eKangyur from the original scanned source. The source of the eKangyur is the scanned LoC edition on tbrc.org, W4CZ5369 (Although it follows the volume order of W22084, the Parphud edition on tbrc.org). Occasionally the print may be illegible due to smudges, and so you may compare with W22084, which as far as I know is nearly identical. Of course, it not really our job to proof read the eKangyur, so don't spend hours checking for typos in the eKangyur; but you may happen to notice an error now and then while checking the source, and in such case you can enter them into the spreadsheet and they can be reported to Esukhia at some point.
